Metadata.Title: Set the HTTPOnly and Secure Flags on Session Cookies
Metadata.DirectLink: Set the HTTPOnly and Secure Flags on Session Cookies

Content.Data: ==What to Do== Set the //Secure// and //HTTPOnly// flags on all sensitive cookies, including session cookies. ==Why== Set the //Secure// flag on all sensitive cookies to protect the contents of the sensitive cookies from eavesdropping attacks. Setting the //Secure// flag on sensitive cookies ensures they are only transferred over connections that are secured by SSL. Set the //HTTPOnly// flag on sensitive cookies to prevent the contents of those cookies from being access by Cross-Site Scripting exploits. The //HTTPOnly// flag prevents the contents of the marked cookie from being accessed by client-side script. ==How== To set the //Secure// and //HTTPOnly// flags on all sensitive cookies: # **Verify that SSL is available.** The //Secure// flag forces cookies to be sent over SSL. SSL has to be available for this to work. # **Identify sensitive cookies.** Session cookies should always be considered sensitive. Enumerate all cookies used by the application. Make a list of cookies that may contain sensitive information. # **Identify code that creates sensitive cookies.** For each sensitive cookie in the list, find the code that creates that cookie. # **Set the //Secure// and //HTTPOnly// flags for each sensitive cookie.** For each piece of code that creates a sensitive cookie, add code that sets the //Secure// and //HTTPOnly// flags for the cookie. Make sure, that when the //Secure// attribute is set for a cookie, it is in response to a request that was made over HTTPS and not HTTP. # **Configure the platform.** Many platform have configuration options that allow setting the //Secure// and //HTTPOnly// flags for session cookies. Please refer to your platform's documentation for information about whether this functionality is available and how to use it.
